RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  

A. 

Power Sector Overview    

3. 
The formulation of power sector development policies is the responsibility of the Ministry 
of Energy and Mineral Resources, which discharges its control and regulatory functions through 
the  Directorate  General  for  Electricity  and  Energy  Utilization  (DGEEU).  The  State  Electricity 
Enterprise (PLN), the state-owned electricity company, is responsible for the development and 
operation  of  the  power  sector  and  serves  over  30  million  consumers.  The  Ministry  for  State-
Owned  Enterprises  exercises  the  sole  shareholder's  powers  on  behalf  of  the  Government. 
PLN's total installed power generation capacity reached 21,000 megawatts (MW) in December 
2001.  PLN’s  assets  include  24,800  circuit-kilometers  (cct-km)  of  transmission  lines;  substation 
capacity  of  50,000  megavolt-ampere  (MVA);  and  medium-  and  low-voltage  lines  totaling 
287,500 cct-km. The Java-Bali power grid has 74% of the installed capacity, and the remainder 
is spread over 1,100 power grids.2 
  
4. 
Electricity is also generated by power plants with an aggregate capacity of about 12,000 
MW.  Large  industries  and  businesses  own  and  operate  the  plants,  and  PLN  customers  own 
about half of these captive power plants, allowing these electricity users to buy power from PLN 
or  generate  their  own.  Since  the  plants  are  unregulated,  sufficient  data  is  not  available  to 
determine the actual amount of electricity used, or the impact of tariffs on PLN’s power demand. 
Independent power producers (IPPs), which are under contract to sell all their power output to 
PLN, have the capacity to generate another 3,000 MW. 
 
5. 
PLN's  power  supply  extends  to  49,000  (84%)  of  58,000  villages,  and  53%  of  the 
estimated  52  million  households  are  PLN’s  customers.  The  reliability  of  power  supply  has 
generally been better than in many other developing member countries (DMCs), and Java-Bali 
has  not  experienced  a  system-wide  power  failure  in  the  past  5  years  despite  PLN’s  financial 
problems.  Industrial  and  commercial  customers  find  the  electricity  tariff  com petitive. Reduction

B. 

Power Sector Development Plan 

7. 
Until  1997,  DGEEU  and  PLN  regularly  prepared  power  sector  development  plans  to 
reflect  an  annual  energy  sales  growth  rate  of  about  12%,  and  resources  were  mobilized  to 
implement  these  plans.  Although  the  plans  were  optimistic,  PLN  could  acquire  resources  to 
implement  new  projects.  In  1997,  about  70%  surplus  generation  capacity  was  available  and 
several  new  power  generation  projects  were  under  implementation,  some  by  IPPs. The crisis 
had two significant impacts: (i) the growth of energy sales slowed, reducing the urgency to add 
new  power  generation  capacity;  and  (ii)  the  electricity  tariffs  could  only  be  gradually  raised  to 
reflect  increased  cost  of  electricity  supply,  so financial performance results of PLN were poor 
and  it  could  not  borrow  for  capital  investment.  These  factors  introduced  considerable 
uncertainties in the power sector planning process, and available resources barely allowed PLN 
to complete ongoing projects.  
 
8. 
The  situation  has  gradually  changed.  The  annual  energy  sales  growth  is  now  about 
10%,  and  although  the  economic  forecasts  still  lack  clarity,  PLN  has  prepared  power  demand 
projections  corresponding  to  annual  economic  growth  of  3.5–6.0%  and  an  increase  in 
electrification ratio4 from 53% to 75% by 2010. A summary of the power development plan, i.e., 
the  forecast  of  demand  growth  and  capacity  additions  required  in  the  power  sector,  is  in 
Appendix  2.  The  electricity  tariff  was  gradually  raised  during  2000–2002, and the Government 
plans to keep raising it to a level of full cost recovery and a reasonable rate of return by 2005. 
The  projected  higher  electricity  sales  revenue  will  allow  PLN  to  meet  the  operating  costs 
(including  power  purchase  from  IPPs)  and  borrow  funds  for  the  new  investment  required  to 
satisfy  power  demand  growth.  A  delay  in  new  investment  will  reduce  the  reliability  of  PLN’s 
power supply, and the Java-Bali power grid could have a power shortfall by 2005. To address 
such  concerns,  large  consumers  may  decide  to  implement  new  captive  power  plants,  which 
would be a less efficient and environment-friendly outcome.

11. 
DGEEU  has  prepared  a  draft  Green  Energy  Plan:  A  Strategy  to  Achieve  Sustainable 
Development.  It  will  help  maximize  the  use  of  renewable  energy  and  promote  energy-efficient 
technologies. The Government will propose a new energy utilization bill, which will cover energy 
resource  management,  renewable  energy  supply  and  utilization,  energy-efficient technologies, 
standards,  environmental  protection,  pricing,  and  measures  to  stimulate  higher  investments 
through  the  private  and  public  sectors.  The  green  energy  plan  includes  consultation  with 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  dissemination  of  information  regarding  advantages 
of renewable energy and energy efficiency. 
 
D. 

Power Sector Policies    

12. 
Based  on  the  Government’s  Power  Sector  Restructuring  Policy  (August  1998),  ADB 
approved a policy-based program loan (the Program) and the assoc iated capacity-building loan 
(TA Loan).6 The Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) also approved a loan of $400 
million,  disbursed  in  two  equal  tranches,  and  linked  to  the  release  of  the  two  program  loan 
tranches. The first program loan tranche of $200 million was disbursed in March 1999 and the 
Board's approval is being sought for the release of the second tranche following the enactment 
and promulgation of the Electricity Law 20 on 23 September 2002.7 
 
13. 
The Program seeks to increase power sector efficiency and make it financially viable by 
establishing  a  competitive  electricity  market  in  Java-Bali. The  new  electricity  law provides the 
necessary legal framework, and stipulates that competition should be introduced within 5 years, 
starting  with  competition  for  power  generation.  The  law  also  requires  creating  an  independent 
regulatory body within 1 year, and unbundling power generation, transmission, distribution, and 
supply.8

To  facilitate  the  transition  to  an  unbundled  power  sector,  the  focus  now  is  on 
decentralization and empowerment of operational units by making them strategic business units 
(SBUs).  The  corporate  office,  which  earlier  made  all  decisions  in  operational  and  investment-
related  matters,  is  now  transforming  itself  as  a  “holding  company”  with  SBUs  as  “virtual” 
subsidiaries. During the past 2 years, many corporate staff have been relocated to SBUs. SBU 
general  managers  now  exercise  full  responsibility  for  energy  sales,  including  the  expansion  of 
the  distribution  network.  The  larger  generation  and  transmission  projects  are  implemented 
under the direct control of the corporate office. However, in the next phase of decentralization, 
SBU  managers  will  share  responsibility  for  procurement  and  be  fully  responsible  for  the 
implementation  of  all  the  projects  in  their  respective  regions.  SBUs  will  eventually  have  the 
flexibility  to  negotiate  agreements  for  power  purchase  at  the  local  level  based  on  projected 
energy  sale  and  revenue.  With  the  strengthening  of  managerial  capacity,  SBUs  are  well 
positioned  to  coordinate  the  development  and  management  of  the  regional  power  sector  with 
the  provincial  and  regency  governments.  When  local  governments  establish  their  financial 
capacity to invest in regional development  and  are  prepared  to  adjust  the  regional  electricity 
tariffs  to  reflect  the  full  cost  of  the  power  supply  in  the  region,  SBUs  are  envisaged  to  be 
separated from PLN as jointly owned subsidiaries. The new electricity law allows such vertically 
integrated  power  companies  in  the  outer  islands  to  be  owned  by  the  private  sector.  Like  any 
network  industry,  economies  of  scale  are  available  in  the  power  sector.  While  administrative 
decentralization may transfer authority to nearly 400 regencies and cities, fragmentation of the 
power sector is not advisable.

The  Kyoto  Protocol  to  the  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate  Change 
specifies  targets  to  reduce  greenhouse  gas  emission  in  developed  countries  from  their  1990 
levels by an average of 5.2% in 2008–2012. Although the Kyoto Protocol is yet to be ratified, a

G. 

ADB’s Strategy in the Power Sector 

24. 
DMCs  should  make  more  energy  available  in  a  least-cost  and  environment-friendly 
manner, and improve access to it for all, particularly the poor. Mobilizing the required resources 
will require establishing greater transparency and a competitive environment to promote private 
sector  investment,  and  increasing  supply-  and  demand-side  efficiencies.  Energy  sector 
development  must  also  be  environmentally  sustainable.  Regional  and  global  environmental 
impacts must thus be mitigated and greater use of renewable energy sources encouraged. To 
ensure  that  its  future  operations  reflect  these  requirements,  ADB  prioritizes reducing poverty, 
promoting  private  sector  involvement,  addressing  regional  and  global  environmental  impacts, 
and  promoting  regional  cooperation.  ADB  interventions  take  into  account  the  varying  physical 
features, resource endowments, and economic standards of DMCs.

change will take place at end-2007, when the competitive electricity market will be established 
in  Java-Bali.  ADB  is  envisaged  to  consider  another  policy-based  loan  to  support  market 
development.

60. 
A  least  cost  analysis  was  carried  out  by  comparing  the  costs  related  to  the  envisaged 
subprojects  and  alternate  diesel-based  power  plants.  Three  considerations  have  been  taken 
into  account:  (i)  future  growth  of  power  demand  and  required  capacity,  (ii)  the  gap  between 
available dependable capacity and required capacity, and (iii) how to close this gap at the least 
cost.  The  subprojects  will  operate  as  base  load  power  plants  and  thereby  reduce  the  use  of

economic  aspects  were  compared.  The  financial  and  economic  superiority  of  the  proposed 
renewable  energy  subprojects  made  them  the  least-cost  option  for  the  power  grid  expansion 
plan.  
 

2. 

Economic Evaluation 

61. 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated for the core subprojects. The 
EIRR  was  determined  by  valuing  costs  and  benefits  in  economic  terms.  Domestic  prices  in 
constant 2002 value were used in economic evaluation. Capital and O&M costs were adjusted 
to remove taxes, duties, and other transfer payments. The local currency expenditures relating 
mostly to nontraded goods were equal to their domestic value, and a shadow exchange rate of 
1.05  was  applied  to  calculate  the  economic  prices  of  traded  goods  from  their  financial  prices 
(based  on  a  standard  conversion  factor  of  0.95).  The  energy  available  for  sale  was  valued  in 
terms of resource cost savings.23 
 
The  EIRR  for  the  four  core  subprojects  was  estimated  at  19.4–22.1%.  The  results 
62. 
showed  that  all  core  subprojects  were  economically  viable  and  the  benefits  resulting  from  the 
individual  subprojects  sufficiently  high  to  justify  subproject  costs,  including  capital  costs.  The 
EIRR  calculation  was  subject  to  sensitivity  analysis  to  test  the  effect  of  possible  unfavorable 
changes in key variables. A summary of the least-cost and economic analysis is in Appendix 8.

The financial analysis of the core subprojects was carried out based on real terms using 
63.

fuel,  and  O&M,  including  those  for  the  associated  distribution  system.  The  financial  benefits

8. 
In  many  ways,  PLN  is  a  well-run  utility:  its  operating  costs  are  low,  transmission  and

Indigenous Peoples  

15. 
A few subprojects will affect indigenous communities. Some are relatively well integrated 
into  Indonesian  society  and  culture,  while  others,  especially  in  Papua,  sharply  differ  in  race, 
culture, society, and political organization from the national mainstream. These differences have 
been  carefully  factored  into  project  activities  to  ensure  compliance  with  the  ADB  indigenous 
peoples policy.  
 
 
General indigenous people policy and procedural provisions are developed in an IPPF. 
16. 
Specific  subproject  issues  will  be  dealt  with  through  an  IPDP  based  on  intensive  participatory 
planning. Depending on the impact’s gravity and the degree of indigenous people's vulnerability, 
the  IPDP  will  either  be  included  in  the  subproject  LARPs  or  prepared  as  a  stand-alone 
document.  One  core  subproject  (Merasap)  will  affect  indigenous  people.  For  the  identified 
noncore  subprojects  in  Papua,  the  preparation  of  individual  IPDPs  will  be  a  condition  for  ADB 
financing.  Community  infrastructure  that  may  be  provided  by  an  IPDP  will  have  to  be 
constructed before the land needed by the subproject is acquired. 
 

1. 

Indigenous People Policy Framework 

17. 
The  IPPF  provides  a  general  introduction  to  indigenous  people  issues  for  the  Project, 
outlines the criteria established by the ADB policy, identifies indigenous people, and provides an 
overview of indigenous communities to be or likely to be affected by the Project. The IPPF also 
sets  the  policy  and  procedural  framework  relevant  for  the  Project  as  a  whole;  outlines  the 
content  of  a  model  IPDP;  and  describes  the  strategy  to  be  followed  in  defining  different  IPDP 
types fitting the degree of impact intensity and relative vulnerability of affected communities. 
 
 
18. 
As for the indigenous people identification criteria, the IPPF establishes that indigenous 
people  are  those  who  in  various  degrees  (i)  descend  from  groups  present  in  specific  areas 
before the establishment of modern states and relative borders, and (ii) maintain distinct self- or 
non-self-ascribed  identities.  Other  identification  criteria  will  be  used  to  establish  the  degree  of 
vulnerability of affected indigenous people and the type of action to be developed for an IPDP: 
(i) use of distinct languages; (ii) active maintenance of sociocultural systems and institutions that 
differ from the sociocultural system and institutional-political tradition of dominant societies; (iii) 
pursuit  of  livelihood  in  the  margins  of  the  market  system;  and  (vi)  maintenance  of  unique  ties 
and attachments to natural resources and ancestral territories.
